Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptive Hybridized DG Methods for Acoustic and Electromagnetic Scattering
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, the investigator and his colleagues will develop, analyze, and implement quasi-optimal adaptive hybridized Discontinuous Galerkin methods for acoustic and electromagnetic scattering problems as described by the Helmholtz equation and the time-harmonic Maxwell equation on bounded domains in two and three dimensional domains using general local bases. These methods feature traditional piecewise polynomial bases as well as special purpose wave elements, and multilevel preconditioned iterative solvers on adaptively refined simplicial, quadrilateral, and hexahedral meshes. The adaptive mesh refinement is driven by residual-type a posteriori error estimators. In particular, the team will prove convergence of the adaptive solution process as well as its quasi-optimality in terms of the computational complexity with respect to a properly specified approximation class. High quality software implementations will be used to test the algorithms and inform the analysis.

Advances in the state of the art in numerical methods for performing acoustic and electromagnetic simulations have potentially high impact in several applications. As an example more accurate simulation of acoustic wave propagation can be used to considerably enhance resolution of medical ultra sound scans, and thus expand the reach of non-invasive diagnostics. The emphasis of this project is the development of novel numerical methods that compute provably accurate approximations of physical acoustics and electromagnetics phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has been concerned with the numerical solution of acoustic and electromagnetic scattering problems, i.e., the deviation of acoustic and electromagnetic waves from a certain path due to non-uniformities in the medium through which they pass. Acoustic waves are simples than electromagnetic waves, because they can be described by the velocity potential which is a scalar quantity. In case of a time-harmonic excitation the wave equation reduces to an indefinite elliptic equation known as the Helmholtz equation. Applications include sodar (sound detection and ranging), sonar (sound navigation and ranging), and ultrasound spectroscopy. On the other hand, the propagation of electromagnetic waves is described by a system of partial differential equations known as the Maxwell equations. Applications include radio waves and microwaves, diffraction of X-rays, and radiation transfer.

The major goal of the project was to develop, analyze, and implement a special class of numerical schemes for the Helmholtz equation and for the time-harmonic Maxwell equations, namely so-called Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods which are finite element approximations featuring discontinuous trial and test functions. Particular emphasis was on adaptive Interior Penalty DG (IPDG) methods and plane wave DG (PWDG) methods.

The major outcomes of the project were to prove quasi-optimal convergence of adaptive IPDG methods for the Helmholtz equation with applications in acoustic scattering and the optimal choice of plane wave directions in PWDG methods for the Helmholtz equation and the time-harmonic Maxwell equations. \\
In particular, the adaptivity was based on a residual-type a posteriori error estimator. The convergence of the adaptive scheme was shown by establishing a reduction property for a weighted sum of the global discretization error and the error estimator. \\
As far as the optimal choice of the plane waves as test and trial functions was concerned, the problem was formulated as a constrained optimal control problem with the direction of the plane waves as controls and the Helmholtz equation or the time-harmonic Maxwell equations as a constraint. The necessary optimality conditions have been established in terms of a coupled system of PDEs for the state and the adjoint state and have been numerically solved by a projected gradient method. It turned out that for problems, where the solution displays axisymmetry, equidistributed directions of the plane waves are almost optimal in the sense that for a small number of plane waves they are close to being optimal, whereas they are practically optimal for a higher number. The situation is very different for problems with a non-symmetric solution as in acoustic and electromagnetic scattering problems with scatterers of complicated geometric shapes.  In these cases an equidistribution of the directions of the plane waves is far from optimal independently of the number of plane waves and the performance of the PWDG method can be significantly improved by determining the optimal directions as the solution of the constrained optimal control problem mentioned above. \\
Further investigations revealed that it is beneficial to use hp-adaptivity in the sense to refine the underlying mesh of the computational domain (h-adaptivity), where the solution  lacks smoothness (e.g., in a vicinity of reentrant corners or material discontinuities), and to increase the number of plane waves (p-adaptivity), where the solution is smooth. A criterion for hp-adaptivity has been developed based on error estimates for the PWDG approximation in terms of the mesh width and the number of plane waves.
